results.title: Outside in...Skin (Captioned)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Full of Life”.
This program looks at the various things that affect our skin. Topics covered include the structure of the skin, the purpose of the skin and the things that influence the state of our skins such as diet, hygiene, age and sun. This program aims to encourage young people to adopt a healthy, balanced way of living. Rated: G.

results.title: Fuelling Up
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Full of Life”.
This program aims to teach young people that diet does not mean the complete denial of nice things to eat, but rather the controlled, planned intake of good quality food - the fuel necessary to power life. Rated: G

results.title: Out: stories of lesbian and gay youth
results.creator_credit: David Adkin, Silva Basmajian and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film explodes some of the myths that provide the foundation for homophobia. It offers insight into the world of several gay and lesbian youth and looks at the people in their lives, identifying some of the difficulties gay youth face. The film attempts to break the damaging silence surrounding sexual orientation and sexual differences.

results.title: Dealing with Discipline Problems (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Jim Thornton and Dave Bell Associates
results.brief_description: A dozen discipline situations filmed at three of Dr Glasser’s model “schools without failure” demonstrates how teachers apply “success concepts” of reality therapy in everyday practice.

results.title: Over-dependency
results.creator_credit: Robert Anderson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The case history of a man whose life is crippled by behavior patterns carried over from a too-dependent childhood. Through therapy he comes to understand the causes of his illness and fear.

results.title: Homeward bound
results.creator_credit: Clem Vallance, Roger Mills, Arts and Entertainment Network and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Around the world in 80 days”.
Homeward bound covers days 28 to 79 of Michael Palin’s (ex- Monty Python) 20th Century attempt to replicate the round-the-world trip of the fictional Phineas Fogg. The video takes us with Michael from Madras to Singapore via a Yugoslav freighter on which Palin works as a deckhand; from Singapore to Hong Kong and Shanghai, where Palin samples snake; from Shanghai to California via the eerie uninhabited world of a giant container ship and then by train, dog sled, balloon and ship on the last leg back to London.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Clem Vallance, Roger Mills, Arts and Entertainment Network and BBC-TV

results.title: Around the world in 80 days
results.creator_credit: Clem Vallance, Roger Mills and BBC
results.brief_description: Complete with visas, running shoes, an inflatable globe and sound advice from Alan Whicker, Michael Palin set off to circumnavigate the world using only forms of transport available to the fictional Phileas Fogg. His Passepartout was a 5-strong film crew, his journey was phenomenal, his deadline was 80 days. -

results.title: Outward bound
results.creator_credit: Roger Mills, Clem Vallance and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Around the world in 80 days”.
In this the first half of his journey, Michael Palin travels from London to Madras, via Venice, Alexandria, Saudi Arabia, Dubai and Bombay. Dropping further and further behind schedule Palin struggles with missed connections, bureaucratic negotiations and seasickness until, after a quick shave by a blind man with a cut-throat blade, he boards the train to Madras, only to find his seat has been given to three different Michael Palins, one of them a woman!

results.title: Outside the golden ring
results.creator_credit: George Lindsey and National Broadcasting Company
results.brief_description: Studies the non-traditional marriages of today - homosexual, older-younger, black-white and the unmarrieds. It opens with a sequence inside a gay bar in Washington, D.C. as two homosexuals tell about their marriage. Other participants in the non-traditional marriages are also interviewed. The film examines the life styles and frustration’s of these marriages and includes analysis and comments by two psychologists and a marriage counsellor.
